head.title: FROM THE INTERACTIVE ENCYCLOPEDIA, 2015 EDITION: WELFARE, END OF

hedline.hl1: FROM THE INTERACTIVE ENCYCLOPEDIA, 2015 EDITION: WELFARE, END OF

block.p: Jason DeParle's definition of the end of welfare was a frightening look into the crystal ball of social-welfare policy outcomes ("From the Interactive Encyclopedia, 2015 Edition: Welfare, End of," Dec. 17).

If policy makers want to end welfare as we know it, they ought to increase the availability of affordable health care, day care and housing. Poor people with access to these basic necessities could then take the low-wage service jobs offered by today's economy and would not have to rely on Government help the way they do now.
